2375E5AB5EEB449388F61C76F6C14D01.description: Assess and revise the action plans as necessary

F1260F0EFD62409FB396ACECAAA9518A.description: Develop, with guidance, criteria to assess one’s commitment to personal standards.

22D37BA65E014B0C901A07E34DFEA713.description: Determine specific criteria to evaluate the design elements of action plans.

47CB8D379EF444D68CB0D06B275185EA.description: Establish the kinds of supports needed to implement the action plan.

D4E963E82E344784AC60E4FB2A8210BF.description: Design action plans that feature personal commitment.

EC2EC45C1A0E451D9F2A470C0BC13437.description: Determine, with support, the elements of a well-designed action plan.

D057D084DC224C439E9318C0AFB3D872.description: Design, implement, and evaluate three sixday action plans that demonstrate personal commitment to responsible health action related to blood-borne pathogen information, safety practices, harmonious relationships, food choices, interpersonal skills, and morality.

F291750FC92843DB93C5CB42790A5E43.description: Apply decisions that will improve personal health and/or the health of others.

8A4A0C17D3DD45648DD79612C98AD4E9.description: Establish personal commitment goals for each unit of study.

F786AE48D146463391C9B896D02A62FE.description: Predict the consequences of such strategies.

0C27A4879C3E4BA8B6A17EA51A89851A.description: Determine strategies of commitment necessary to meet individual goals.

4412CACB7E1B4397A29EDD096616DD85.description: Examine factors that affect one’s commitment related to personal goals.

787AEABC8729436384DA3FEF5F85F2A8.description: Propose health opportunities and challenges related to each unit of study.

EBAE58631B5146C1963C0CA49035B729.description: Examine health opportunities and challenges to establish personal commitment goal statements related to blood-borne pathogen information, safety practices, harmonious relationships, food choices, interpersonal skills, and morality.

8F3E9CF7BC2A40909CEEF5E056F5956D.description: Examine when personal commitment might be supported and/or threatened.

1D6BECD8568F4401943151A66FBA269A.description: Recognize the role of personal commitment in making decisions.

F9878C8C5AEB41969FE6779C9853FC91.description: Decide on ways to build personal commitment into the decision-making process.

A946C88038634B7B8243F60F2B13179B.description: Review decision-making processes (Grade 6) and recognize types of decision making.

0CE70230E0C14B7D8986C8AA8076AD82.description: Determine the benefits of using a decision-making process.

A310156558284E288118FD63F9B18B38.description: Examine and demonstrate personal commitment in making health decisions related to blood-borne pathogen information, safety practices, harmonious relationships, food choices, interpersonal skills, and morality .

976E372E3B784562847CCEE4FAE46BFD.description: Make informed decisions based on health-related knowledge.

D396B37888EA4207BE14CE83DCE92963.description: Determine situations when one may be required to assert personal beliefs in the face of opposition.

A1E2AFE3543E41069F3B955270B4D22F.description: Explore, question, and appreciate a wide range of human values, virtues, and abilities that support “the common or greater good” within the contexts of daily life.

04F589CC840D4CA6BD75FE659C17EA1D.description: Question assumptions and stereotypes in relation to different customs, beliefs, attitudes, and opinions.

3134022C17514B8D81ABE52017D98961.description: Distinguish between rights, needs, whims, privileges, and responsibilities.

7087D95D711F41E0A1783B1F6394DDF5.description: Explore the source and rationale of social precepts/principles (e.g., prohibitions, rules, rights, norms in everyday life).

E63D8C11D1194A6AA8947DF9591CB70F.description: Express an understanding of how norms, trends, and values in society influence self, others, and relationships.

40BF2EDBBD6C48D0B1A6B6DC0FA5A4D5.description: Appraise virtues as the quality of doing what is right and avoiding what is wrong.

F78DA0C8ACEF45D68E532D6553F1C8EC.description: Investigate possible relationships and/or tensions among values (e.g., values of integrity and honesty).

F4F8D3C8A65C4164A699361EEBA02F7C.description: Analyze how one’s identity, and moral code is created through contact with others who are the same and/or different.

1E09EC093F594FB0AAABFDB2D2C7749A.description: Explore and discuss moral maxims, stories, parables, and guiding visions of many cultures.

52E6C328406945069432691B67C12947.description: Locate sources and evaluate information, according to specific criteria, about morality.

D604993D81AD41F0A7BA8D80578F4C0A.description: Investigate and express an understanding of possible discrepancies in morals (e.g., beliefs, ethics, virtues, understanding of right/wrong) that may determine and/or affect the commitment to the well-being of self, family, community, and the environment.

F8755D6FC7C1422487E2CB10657D1038.description: Assess the importance of avoiding negative peer pressure/ attachment for the sake of belonging.

5FFFFA8705994E8B88CF31C511E4969D.description: Analyze the traits of assertive people for the purpose of designing and delivering assertive messages.

393598B387614DBB9AA0D86AA40ABB06.description: Define the terms passive, assertive, and aggressive and describe related behaviours.

5C1E42A5B4C846E094FCE426E8FE9EC0.description: Describe and practise a minimum of five strategies to resist peer pressure (e.g., demonstrate physical confidence, say no and leave, provide a reason or an excuse, offer an alternative, use humour).

9188BF0BBDC346F495E118B4A36183D7.description: Demonstrate the ability to stand up for others, practise inclusionary behaviours, and refrain from any form of ridicule.

736E43C829384EB29C5BD309F32FA58F.description: Distinguish what is meant by “harassment” and demonstrate ways to respond to and/or prevent it.

4A75E616FFE04DF2B3F93C1C11876BAF.description: Express insights in response to the statement that resisting peer pressure takes personal commitment, skill, and practice.

A0FB0B63E2424057AD11720048EF928B.description: Examine similarities and differences in the peer pressures faced by different genders, socio-economic backgrounds, family structures, sexual orientations, ages, and cultures.

2E4A90938119470492A1CFF4F7924094.description: Examine how peer pressure may be positive or negative.

A81260FCDEAE4B22AA34103ED78BE9CE.description: Compare the traits of a friend and those of a valued peer group member.

B5E8D5E194434F8DA98D4D20B0FCC015.description: Analyze peer norms and trends and reflect on the consequences of following and/or resisting them.

9E83F754B0A44953BCA0B9E2E1ADAD35.description: Locate sources and evaluate information, according to specific criteria, about interpersonal skills.

42ED44A6123642639E40926EE282F199.description: Demonstrate interpersonal skills, including assertiveness skills, to effectively and skillfully manage peer pressure (e.g., alcohol and drugs, exclusionary behaviours, family expectations, academic pressures, rules/laws).

22FDA5EB8051414A82DB92A94A647093.description: Analyze changes to Canada’s Food Guide through the decades and hypothesize why particular changes were made.

9B9FE487895A4A8CB0CB76862BD37F72.description: Prepare a three-day family food menu by applying nutritional knowledge to make nutritious selections (based on Canada’s Food Guide) using a variety of given family food budgets and/or situations.

215C2102DC904CCA8EA40CF165CD98CB.description: Analyze food labels for personal food choices for sodium, sugar, fat, and calorie content among similar products.

58C468CFA25B4E75A1F82A276D773F43.description: Track and analyze personal food consumption for one week (based on Canada’s Food Guide).

912FABE4469747BE8A0C013EFA18B935.description: Apply guidelines for healthy eating as presented in Canada’s Food Guide.

6FF02EC69BEC43BAB37E051E48D37AED.description: Analyze persuasion, propaganda, and other techniques (e.g., loaded words, unsubstantiated claims) used by individuals or organizations to influence judgement about what foods are healthy and what foods to purchase.

1BD67263883147C6BD40F15A3C28FB8D.description: Examine the consequences of/of not evaluating information about healthy eating.

A77FB21E3EF54A4CA3D73B8682B9C60C.description: Locate sources and evaluate information, according to specific criteria, about healthy eating.

F070945B38B644AC8CE98F04FA4FEEDB.description: Determine how and where to access healthy eating information.

BE5D1763725D4A1D84FC939B25CF4110.description: Evaluate personal food choices and needs by applying accurate and current nutritional knowledge (e.g., content labels).

0377D952BA5142199EFE53DBACB828CA.description: Demonstrate the basics of two or three strategies for reestablishing harmony and for resolving/managing conflict.

7D28F080F33045F4B2834464A6D0C71E.description: Examine what is meant by negotiation, mediation, anger management, compromise, consensus building, and other means of resolving/managing conflict.

86CCA284C34F453E8DDEEFC8EA59103D.description: Demonstrate and adapt strategies of conflict management in a range of contexts.

AB2FB84541D44EFFAAE43DBE7B8FDE29.description: Examine the causes and effects of abuse in relationships and develop personal commitment to non-violent and helpful behaviours.

8D62967E868A46F38BA09F3E2B2FAFBC.description: Reduce/avoid barriers to communicating clearly and constructively.

03CCEC13010B4842B689EA2615805170.description: Assess the impact of conflict on the health (i.e., physical, mental, emotional, spiritual) of self and others.

1E558992E5104CC7972CF7509912F7AA.description: Analyze the connections between self-esteem and personal conflict management strategies.

FB57D5FBDEFF424E89F7787023173949.description: Analyze personal strategies for dealing with conflict (e.g., reduce/avoid barriers to communicating clearly and constructively).

CD919F9C626F4A429DB2B5F11BED7A09.description: Propose why some disagreements lead to conflict and some do not.

B1AD01CE573D45B5924F51414D59F0E8.description: Conclude that a certain degree of disagreement in relationships is normal.

294D3E2869824A35B6935A6FBAF70CBE.description: Examine how disagreements are not the same as conflicts.

35D40AB699CF4BEAB00680783B98AC74.description: Create an informed personal definition of conflict.

9B01ECFEE3F74FA6B641B82007E53329.description: Locate sources and evaluate information, according to specific criteria, about relationships and conflict.

68F42D873A584FD0901A1F0C61A835C5.description: Express insights into what makes a relationship harmonious.

050949BF3FD945F2863BFC8ABD101845.description: Demonstrate a personalized and coherent understanding of the importance of nurturing harmony in relationships (with self, others, and the environment), and apply effective strategies to re/ establish harmony when conflict arises.

206D6EBD6F184DB5B6DCACDBEBB36733.description: Develop and apply basic first aid strategies.

22A79CA30A99483DB0B539C65F6D9C64.description: Examine the roles of a variety of first aid experts within the community and the kinds of available first aid supports.

CA245DD13B0C4A179CB7387808794A68.description: Prioritize basic first aid skills to acquire (according to needs and interests of self and of community).

52105451371948988D2A27B7226DBE5E.description: Demonstrate the ability to “think ahead” and assess/weigh the impact of actions on the safety of self and others.

9818EBC53C5A4D628C7B9058BF8663EC.description: Assess the consequences of practising/not practising personal safety.

18F7290C01FE4D79829383E6CC621E80.description: Analyze how personal safety practices help to keep self and others safe.

515493FE6DB54FF0B3947DC22978604B.description: Examine possible situations at home and at school that may require basic first aid.

AD6E37D0CB67452D91A2BA4529B5DDED.description: Develop and appraise individual capabilities and assess individual limitations with respect to safety practices and first aid.

6EF32E2C8E0A49E7A28A6704B137814B.description: Locate sources and evaluate information, according to specific criteria, about safety practices and first aid skills.

9A34F663BE7E4CD4A84B28BC8E444EE3.description: Commit to personal safety practices while acquiring basic first aid knowledge and skills.

B5DD06F24CF3464C90A0A84038C3743B.description: Determine behaviours that may increase and those that may decrease the risk of blood-borne infections (e.g., tattoo, piercing).

914B86D372D446C9847CD00206087B22.description: Describe the formal and/or informal HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C resources/supports in one’s community.

E7329427B2804DBD9F481A082653CB01.description: Examine knowledge related to blood borne pathogens, including HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C: transmission of HIV and Hepatitis C, signs and symptoms of HIV and Hepatitis C infections, body’s immune system and its destruction by the HI virus, and AID syndrome caused by HIV infection.

99F81A57C4AE4E9B87F483823060AD66.description: Analyze implications of/of not evaluating sources of and information about blood-borne infections.

C673F01C92A04D769B22F0B835D210EA.description: Ask questions that lead to deeper understanding of HIV/ AIDS and Hepatitis C (e.g., How do decisions, commitment, and actions related to HIV/AIDS vary depending on peoples’ perceptions?).

3AF6F0C3C5044CB782977DCD022007B3.description: Examine personal knowledge in terms of what is already known about HIV and Hepatitis C.

C37311ABF01C4172848E13CA0F887A45.description: Examine the role of and determine the influence of technology (e.g., radio, print, television, Internet, cell phones, personal listening devices) in gathering, processing, and using HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C information.

D7558EE0F2B849799476C1FCABCF02D3.description: Distinguish between primary and secondary sources of HIV/ AIDS information, and of expert and non-expert sources.

3BDABBDF0E074096AD171D69F3024699.description: Locate sources and evaluate information, according to specific criteria, about behaviours that do/do not put one at risk of HIV and/or Hepatitis C infection.

F51711950E5443089602700D0CC7ED4A.description: Examine critically and use purposefully bloodborne pathogen information/ education, including HIV and Hepatitis C, for the purpose of committing to behaviours that do not put one at risk of infection or co-infection.

9A1BAC73048F4FFFAF92E419485ED20D.description: Describe and practise strategies that support self to act in accordance with own understanding of human values and virtues.

C96F8C491D754993901CB5D46632B654.description: Express insights into the understanding of the concept of “inner self” and demonstrate understanding of, and appreciation for, own inner resources.

A6D958B69C0F429993597C1B0F5BBFD3.description: Justify the kinds of supports needed to commit to personal standards.

1AADE2A3922446AC9C1F71A77507234B.description: Develop and apply strategies that parallel one’s actions with personal standards.

70BC9923F6B241B7B4BD0723C1E03BEB.description: Analyze possible discrepancies between what people say they commit to and what people actually “show they commit to”.

692017E800AD4AA48D63A0650FE4C904.description: Express insights into the connections between commitment to personal standards and healthy decision making.

4B737081B9314260BA5D52F487BC3B87.description: Examine factors (both positive and negative) that influence one’s commitment to personal standards.

92EB5F9B8A2B42DBB326B6C057339637.description: Analyze when personal standards (see Grade 6) may be reinforced or challenged.

D8CE38FEB0FA47DEB34F30233714B9AA.description: Investigate the concept of ‘resiliency’ and determine its importance in personal commitment.

1E8EF0F931944D44A590AA824EF8A4A4.description: Locate sources of and evaluate information (including text, multimedia, web-based, human) according to specific criteria, about personal commitment.

05D38761ABDD43C7A30E7F47E0F04C15.description: Establish and use strategies to commit to and act upon personal standards (see grade 6) for various aspects of daily living over which an individual has control.

1F19CBB460DA4CF9A62D1BEF97C22B96.description: Develop the understanding, skills, and confidences necessary to take action to improve health.
